poem:
Aotearoa's Echo  

In the land where winds contest,  
a paper bill stirs the deep,  
ancestors whispering in unrest,  
the ink dry, yet the wounds seep.  
Hollow words, justice wrests,  
from roots entwined in sacred keep,  
a nation's pact put to test,  
in silence, the spirits weep.

Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
